Out of 8 blocks, 7 were affected by the blaze. Rescue and investigation efforts continued into Thursday (27th) night and were still unfinished. The Fire Services Department estimated that forced-entry search and rescue operations would be completed by Friday (28th) at 9 a.m. As of early Friday morning (Hong Kong time), 83 deaths and 77 injuries were confirmed, including 11 firefighters among the injured. The government and police launched an investigation and arrested three people on suspicion of manslaughter. According to official announcements, the three arrested were responsible persons from the company in charge of Wang Fuk Courtâ€™s maintenance â€” two directors and one engineering consultant. Late at night, scaffolding on the exterior wall of Hong Tai House reignited, reaching nearly ten stories high before being extinguished half an hour later. Pope Leo XIV sent a telegram of condolences, praying for the deceased and for the victims. This fire claimed 83 lives, surpassing the 1962 Sham Shui Po fire that killed 44 and injured 21, leaving hundreds homeless. In November 1996, the five-alarm fire at the Garley Building in Kowloon caused 41 deaths and 81 injuries. The deadliest fire in Hong Kongâ€™s recorded history remains the 1918 Happy Valley Racecourse blaze, which killed 614 people. Key Points1. Political Priorities of the Hong Kong GovernmentOn Thursday (27th), the Chinese self-media outlet Niutanqin, which has a background linked to Chinese state media and hundreds of thousands of followers, published a commentary blaming bamboo scaffolding for fueling the fire at Hong Fu Court in Tai Po. Chief Executive John Lee told reporters in the evening that the Development Bureau would meet with the construction industry to discuss a roadmap for replacing bamboo scaffolding with metal alternatives. In its article titled â€œTwo Unexpected Aspects of the Hong Kong Fireâ€, Niutanqin claimed that bamboo scaffolding contributed to the spread of the fire, citing smoking or the use of substandard safety nets as major safety management oversights, while failing to mention the role of government departments. The commentary further implied that Hong Kong lags behind China in construction materials, noting that bamboo scaffolding has long been replaced by metal structures in China, whereas bamboo scaffolding remains common across Hong Kongâ€™s streets.After inspecting the disaster site at Hong Fu Court in the afternoon, John Lee stated that the government had begun inspecting buildings across the city undergoing major exterior wall repairs with scaffolding protection nets. He added that the Development Bureau would meet with the construction industry to discuss the roadmap for replacing bamboo scaffolding with metal structures, stressing that the government would assist the industry in transitioning. However, he did not address the responsibilities of government departments in the incident or the support for affected residents. Moreover, in policy execution, the Housing Bureau, Buildings Department, Fire Services Department, and Labour Department all appeared to have lapses. Pan Zhuohong, Chairman of China Science Monitoring, remarked: â€œIf it involves public housing or subsidized housing, the Housing Bureauâ€™s independent review team should be responsible. The Fire Services Department has the duty to eliminate fire hazards, and the Labour Department is responsible for protecting workers on scaffolding. These four departments are the enforcement bodies of this technical document.â€ 2. Bid-Rigging ConcernsResidents reported that the ownersâ€™ corporation selected the most expensive contractor, â€œHong Yip Construction Engineering Co. Ltd.,â€ which had been repeatedly found in violation and prosecuted. The corporation was also suspected of bid-rigging, yet refused to allow questions from homeowners, leading to residents surrounding the chairman for questioning. The corporationâ€™s consultant and local district councillor, DAB member Wong Bik-kiu, criticized former Democratic Party councillor Cheung Wing-fai for â€œstirring troubleâ€ over bid-rigging oversight, while supporting the current corporation.
